turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well, I -- I don't hesitate because I have any question as to about what -- about our position that there has to be both an interception and a divulgence.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I don't mean your position really that but -- but 605.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Yes, 605, says that.
There must be --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And what is the --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: -- interception and divulgence.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And if the record is barren of -- of an interception --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Of divulgence.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Of divulgence.
I beg your pardon.
Where do we go from there?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: I think there can be no violation but that I think that in -- the reason that I -- that I have difficulty with that case, this situation, is that -- that some of the language of the Court in dealing with this problem, deals with wiretapping, as such, as being an underhanded bad business.
I think it comes from reading the -- the dissents -- the dissents in the -- on -- on the original Olmstead case.
And so one has a feeling that if there is this kind of -- of interception in the case that we have a problem as to the -- the reception of the evidence and the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I should think if lower courts talk that way.
I don't know anything about it there's all the more reasons for getting clarity into the business?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well, I --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: This is all the more reasons for your being more robust than you are in standing --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- on that position.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well I -- well I can assure Your Honor that --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No, I don't want to put you --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: No, I can assure Your Honor that there's no -- there is no hesitation on my part on that -- on that issue.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right, I --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: But it's clearly our position that there must be both interception and divulgence before there's a violation of 605.
There must be --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- (Voice Overlap) 605 doesn't say or doesn't say anybody who intercepts (Inaudible) is -- be guilty and can be civilly, sued, does it?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: It does not.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, we can't go on the general atmosphere that interception is bad business.God knows nobody thinks worst of it than I do.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: That's right.
The statute requires both and -- and so far -- so far as I can ascertain, there's no -- nothing in this record with respect to divulgence.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: May I ask you Mr. Davis since the statute does require a rule, what do you say about what Judge Medina said on page 4A of what he thinks where he said we have no alternative other than to hold by tapping the wire, interception in the communications made by a telephone and divulging at the trial what they had overheard, the New York police officer violates the federal statute.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: That's what Judge Medina said.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: So, are you challenging it?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: I find no evidence of any divulgence at the trial except as I had explained to the court as a basis for objecting to the introduction of the evidence.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you challenge that statement in your brief?
It is rather --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: We --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- it's rather unusual to the court to go against the -- what the court says as to the facts of case --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well, we --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: -- we have not -- we have not Mr. Justice Black, we haven't argued in our brief in this case and quite frankly until Mr. Justice Frankfurter pressed me on this one.
I hadn't realized the importance of this to the -- to the case.
We haven't --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I thought it (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: -- argued the absence of divulgence here.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I thought (Inaudible) might have been the reason why you have the statement there.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- there.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: -- I -- one reason -- one reason that -- that this comes up and -- and maybe without proper preparation is that we don't have any proper record in this case because of the way this thing comes to this Court.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That being true, wouldn't we have to accept

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- what the court held?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well, you -- well we'd -- you have before you the transcript of the proceeding below which -- which will show you everything that was -- I mean there's no question as to what went on at the trial.
That transcript is on file with the Court.
So there's no --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: He found that there was both interception and divulgence.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well, he makes that remark.
I don't know whether his mind was --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- (Voice Overlap) at the Court's opinion, isn't it?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: That's certainly in the Court's opinion whether it's a conscious weighing of any evidence or whether it's a -- an assumption, I don't know.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, Mr. Davis, if at the trial either it's before the courts or before the jury, one of the officers testified to this conversation so far as 11 pieces are concerned.
How can it be said that there is no divulgence?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well, I think that that would have been a divulgence of that information, yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, it was.
It was there and it was a divulgence, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Yes, but I -- but I don't think --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well then --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: -- that the petitioner -- the petitioner can now object because on cross-examination in opposing the in -- the admissibility of the evidence can object because he brought out a message of this kind.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, you brought the fruits of it -- of it there and wasn't he entitled in his conscience to (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: It's certainly wasn't entitled to.
That was the only way that he could challenge it and that's the way he did challenge it.
But that doesn't --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And indeed --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: -- mean that the Government --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- there was this divulgence then -- then --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: And this --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- if there was a divulgence, then Judge Medina is right, isn't he?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well, not a divulgence in the sense that should exclude the evidence from the -- from the -- should result in an -- sa violation.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, does the -- does the statute say that it shall not be divulged to a jury?
It says it shall not be divulged.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well, if there was a violation by the police officer in -- in answering this question in court, if there was such a violation, it is not attributable to the Government.
It's attributable to the petitioner and the petitioner cannot then object to be introduced and introduction of some other evidence on the ground that he caused the divulgence.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, when you -- when you bring a -- a witness into the case and -- and produce evidence that amounts to the introduction of -- of poisoned evidence, can you hide behind -- behind that --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- and say that --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: I'm not trying to --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- we don't -- we -- we're not responsible for any divulgence because the -- the defendant tried to show and did show that it was illegally obtained?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: We're not trying to hide behind it, Your Honor.
We think we had an entire right to challenge this evidence and to bring out this -- and to bring this out before the Court.
I mean he had to say --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: -- in order to challenge it he couldn't do anything else.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Suppose a police officer had said or asked the court's ruling not to -- to be allowed not to answer this question because to answer it would commit a crime.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: I -- I think [Laughs] it would -- it would be an impossible situation.
I mean there'd be no way -- that would mean there would be no way of challenging -- challenging the admissibility of this evidence.
If you couldn't talk -- maybe you didn't have to tell the details of the conversation.
Maybe all they had to do was to say there was wiretapping.
Maybe that would have been --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I don't see -- I don't -- myself --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: And that wouldn't be a divulgence with -- of the message.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I don't see how the -- how it was necessary to tell that there's interception in order to tell that this was evidence.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well, they wanted to find out whether this resulted from the interception.
And in order to find out whether this seizure resulted from the interception, they have to find out what was said in the interception and that's why these questions were asked.
And whether it was proper or whether it wasn't, I don't know.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What I'm suggesting --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: But --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- and I (Inaudible) the policeman might say I'm -- I'm familiar with the law and I'm -- my -- my lips are sealed because that would make a crime which heretofore wasn't a crime because there's been no divulgence.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: And then we would come down to the question of who has the burden of proof showing that there is a connection between the evidence and the -- and the alleged interception whether it is the objector or whether it's the -- the Government.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: I don't see how you get around what Justice Black pointed out.
The record (Inaudible)
Here we got the Court of Appeals saying it was divulged, what difference does it make and he was in -- it was divulged it was divulged.
You're trying to use the --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: But -- but I'm not trying to use anything that was divulged, Your -- Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well, the fruits.
That's the difference --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: But I'm not -- yes.
What [Laughs] -- what I'm trying to -- what we're trying to use is the evidence which occurred before that and if there was divulgence, it was divulgence which the petitioner cannot obtain.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: So, then you get down to a very narrow point.

If you -- if you are -- if you have to live with this record, this statement then it seems to me what you said before indicate that you cannot use the conversation itself even though by a state officer in this proceeding.
And then the only question is whether the fruits could be used --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: That is --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I'd say that's -- that's all there is.
But you're -- you're bound by this (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Maybe it was our fault deciding the case, too.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well, I'm not --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: -- sure.
I -- I think we're bound by -- by the transcript which is before you --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But the thing is --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: -- of -- of what actually occurred.
I mean --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And this is a finding by the Court of Appeals.
How can we overlook that?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Well, if it --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Look at the record and see if it's going out.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: If there's no -- if there's no word in --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: -- the record --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I don't see that we're borne by what an opinion (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: If there's no word in the record (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- (Voice Overlap) state the fact's inaccurate.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Actually, you see -- actually, Your Honor, there was no -- there was no consideration in our brief and of -- so far as I know it until this argument as to whether or not there had been a prior divulgence in this case.

I mean we had assumed that there were two issues in this case, one, an illegal act by the state officials under 605 and whether still the evidence should be admissible or two, that the act was not illegal because it was -- it was justified by the state -- by the state constitutional laws.
This additional issue which has now arisen is something which is confused on -- on the record in view of Judge Medina's statement and can only be ascertained by reading the -- the transcript itself.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: How big of a transcript is this, do you know?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: It's not long.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It's not long.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is the record here?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Are there old records?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes, it is here.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Is it found (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Now, I wonder --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: -- well in fact if the transcript itself found is the question.

turn.speaker: george_j_todaro
turn.label: Mr. George J. Todaro
turn.text: I think that there was the -- the question of divulgence was admitted by the U.S. Attorney's office when we went to the United States Court of Appeals.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You mean it's -- his -- his admission is in the record?

turn.speaker: george_j_todaro
turn.label: Mr. George J. Todaro
turn.text: I -- I'll supply a copy of his statement on appeal.
I mean to the U.S. Attorney's Office where they concede that there was a divulgence.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And they're free to agree.
Is that where he -- and therefore he -- and therefore he conceded it?
When you say he conceded it on appeal --

turn.speaker: george_j_todaro
turn.label: Mr. George J. Todaro
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- in the brief filed in the Court of Appeals?

turn.speaker: george_j_todaro
turn.label: Mr. George J. Todaro
turn.text: I believe so.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, the Department of Justice has those briefs haven't they Mr. Davis?

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Yes, we have them.

turn.speaker: george_j_todaro
turn.label: Mr. George J. Todaro
turn.text: I'd agree, though.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: If you --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- see the entire record here, the evidence and everything that transpired at the trial for it.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Mr. Justice Black, I think that nothing has been certified when the petition -- of course when the petition was filed in this case as is usual and now that the -- just the -- the opinion of the court below is -- is made in the appendix to the -- to the petitioner.
When it is granted by then generally a record is printed.
Of course, there was no time to print a record and I am not -- I haven't checked but I do not know whether there's even a certified copy of the transcript.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What is --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: What I have referred --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: If it's not a record we'd have to go about --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: You'd have to accept it for the (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- and if there is a record, we could look at the record.

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: That is right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Plus also what justify your friend -- that --

turn.speaker: john_f_davis
turn.label: Mr. John F. Davis
turn.text: Anything conceded --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- it reads in the -- in the Court of Appeals the concession by the U.S. Attorney office.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. (Voice Overlap).

turn.speaker: george_j_todaro
turn.label: Mr. George J. Todaro
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice.

I just want to point out that Section 605 also states as follows “or they use the same or information therein contained for his own benefit or for the benefit of another that entitled, thereto, making use of the information obtained if they have to use of the information following the -- the bringing in the matter in the United States District Court for prosecution.
With regards to the record, I want to say that we didn't print the record because under the Lustig case, I believe that the findings of the Court of Appeals are binding upon this Court.
Now, this 11 pieces going is not a figment of an imagination --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible) -- Mr. Todaro, I -- I just obtained from the clerk what appears to be all there is of a record submitted and included in it is your appendix in the Court of Appeals which is a -- in a brief presented but apparently with all of the testimony that those two, the wiretap and all the rest of it by the witnesses we'll call it transit and so forth.

turn.speaker: george_j_todaro
turn.label: Mr. George J. Todaro
turn.text: You have it all before you?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: It seems to be this is it.
Did that have all of that in it?

turn.speaker: george_j_todaro
turn.label: Mr. George J. Todaro
turn.text: (Inaudible) No.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: It doesn't have the whole trial record but it --

turn.speaker: george_j_todaro
turn.label: Mr. George J. Todaro
turn.text: No, no.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- seems to be --

turn.speaker: george_j_todaro
turn.label: Mr. George J. Todaro
turn.text: No, no.
That's merely a certified copy of the record of the Circuit Court of Appeals.
That is -- there's certification with respect to the Court of Appeals.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And I think there's all the testimony, the testimony of John A. Francis for the Government.

turn.speaker: george_j_todaro
turn.label: Mr. George J. Todaro
turn.text: Has it got testimony of Mr. Murphy you're supposed --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That's surnamed (Inaudible) for the Government side.

turn.speaker: george_j_todaro
turn.label: Mr. George J. Todaro
turn.text: With Mr. Murphy --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That's all there are -- just -- (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: george_j_todaro
turn.label: Mr. George J. Todaro
turn.text: That's this Murphy, the district attorney of New York County testified to the actual divulgence and these 11 pieces was not -- was not obtained as a figment of the imagination of anyone.
It was conceded by everyone.
The U.S. Attorney conceded.
The Circuit Court of Appeals knew that that was brought out at the trial.
And there was no question about it.
Even the Solicitor General in his brief refers to 11 pieces going -- where do these 11 pieces go and come from?
It took part during the trial as an officer of the court would make a statement of this sort unless he knew that it happened.

Now, the -- the -- and the Circuit Court judge in his review of the facts, page 3A of the appendix says -- states, “On May 10th, 1956 by listening in on a conversation over the telephone between appellant and some other person, the state police learned that 11 pieces will be transported that night at a certain time and place in New York City.”
Now, this is just Medina talking.
He'd learned that -- he states that the police learned that 11 pieces were going.
Well, that must transpired the -- that it'd taken place during the trial that somebody testified 11 pieces were going that -- that night and that's exactly why they followed the car.
They thought they're going to get 11 pieces of narcotic instead they found 11 cans of alcohol.
Now, then there's no dispute about that.

I don't think there's any serious dispute on the part of the Government that this conversation -- that this tap didn't take place, that this conversation wasn't overheard and this wasn't testified to in Court.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You mean that they'd testified to actually what they overheard.

turn.speaker: george_j_todaro
turn.label: Mr. George J. Todaro
turn.text: Correct.

Other -- otherwise, how would Justice Medina say that on May 10th, 1956, by listening in on a conversation on the telephone between the appellant and some other person, the state police officer learned that 11 pieces would be transported that night at a certain time and place in New York City?
Having heard that conversation over a tapped telephone, they followed that car and then they were disappointed.
They only found 11 cans of alcohol and they couldn't make an arrest for narcotics.
Now, as far as the record is concerned, if Your Honor wants to -- I need to go by and get all the record and file a supplemental brief, all right.
But I don't think it's necessary because all along the line, the U.S. Attorney has conceded the tap, it has conceded the divulgence.
The only question is that I brought out the tap.
Sure enough, I might have brought it out when I questioned the police officers as to whether there was a tap on the telephone and that they got some information on the telephone.
And having got that information, they followed this car.
They overheard something and they followed the car.
But how else can I bring about -- how else could I proceed under the second Nardone case it's incumbent upon me to first -- to establish that there was a tap.
Now, in this case, if Your Honors please, I have exactly 10 minutes preparation.
There was another attorney involved.

There was a conflict of interest in the last minute, I was in the case and Judge Walsh wouldn't consent to an adjournment and I borrowed a piece of paper from the U.S. Attorney to -- to proceed with the trial.
I know nothing about the case.
So, when I got up to cross examine, I don't know, something hit me maybe there was a wiretap and I asked the foolish question and just expected to get a big no, when I got a big yes.
And then I had something to -- to play ball, start the cycle.
Now, with regard to the validity of the statute of New York --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So, that explains -- that explains the answer to the question of -- the Chief Justice's question.
There was no motion to suppress.

turn.speaker: george_j_todaro
turn.label: Mr. George J. Todaro
turn.text: What -- oh yes.
There was a motion to suppress that during the trial though.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I don't --

turn.speaker: george_j_todaro
turn.label: Mr. George J. Todaro
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: but not (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: george_j_todaro
turn.label: Mr. George J. Todaro
turn.text: Prior to that, no.
No, I -- I -- it was only equivalent to 10 minutes with that case.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I understand that.
That explains that.

turn.speaker: george_j_todaro
turn.label: Mr. George J. Todaro
turn.text: Oh sure.
Otherwise, I would have made a motion --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: george_j_todaro
turn.label: Mr. George J. Todaro
turn.text: -- to suppress it via divulgence, Mr. Chief Justice.
As to the question of the -- the valid -- the conflict between the state law and the United -- in 605, we did not really raise that issue.
The Government raised it.
I presume because of Justice Medina's ruling that the -- as soon as the officer testified, he violated a federal act.
I'm inclined to agree with the court below because the two -- two statutes are diametrically opposed to each other and both cannot survive.

One is destructive of the other because one says no person shall intercept, and it doesn't mean except the office of the State of New York, while the other will say, we may intercept under certain condition.
Now, this is a law of general application.
If it -- it involves the whole United States.
It does not exclude the State of New York from its -- from abiding by it and the legislature of the State of New York cannot put Congress out of business by legislating in a different way.

It would seem to me that they're -- that they're diametrically opposed and there's a be conflict that must be resolved in favor of the Congress of the United States and the policy of the Congress of the United States.
Now, may I add and close here that there have been repeated attempts made to outlaw wire -- that is to amend 605 by permitting limited wiretapping by Congress.
And the omission being that despite the pressure from our -- some of our governmental agencies, the Congress of United States has refused and still refuses to change 605.
Now, it would indicate that they have a good reason why they don't want to change 605.
And on -- if Congress wishes to change 605, and permit the legislature of the State of New York to have limited wiretapping, Congress can certainly do it by passing the proper act.
While 605 stands at -- this now that no person shall intercept the communication, as I've said before, no person means zero and zero cannot be made into numerical numbers other than zero.
Thank you.
